newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - July 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - July 23.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- MING PAO -- Solicitor-general Daniel Fung said the Court of Appeal had no power to rule on the legality of the provisional legislature. He said if courts ruled the body was unlawful, Hong Kong would be plunged into a state of emergency.

-- Beijing instructed provinces and cities to set up a system to report on local emergencies to prevent overseas media and hostile forces from using certain incidents to mislead international opinion.
-- APPLE DAILY -- One of the major issues discussed during a meeting of top Chinese officials was the introduction of the shareholding system to China's state-owned enterprises.
-- TIN TIN DAILY -- A survey on political figures in China and Taiwan showed Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen was more popular than President Jiang Zemin among Hong Kong people.
-- TA KUNG PAO -- China's economy grew by 9.5 percent in the first half of the year.

-- The newly-appointed leader of the Sino-British Joint Liaison Group's Chinese side, Wang Guisheng, siad the JLG was not a centre of power and would not be involved in the administration of the Hong Kong government.
-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Political foes of Chinese President Jiang Zemin were opposing his three candidates for promotion to the Politburo Standing Committee.
-- Moves by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority to pre-empt speculation in the Hong Kong dollar appear to have worked, with the Hong Kong dollar strengthening on Tuesday.

-- HONG KONG STANDARD -- It was revealed that Hong Kong had admitted only 99 one-way permit holders -- mainland Chinese immigrants -- each day between January to April, less than two-thirds of the daily quota of 150.
